metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Go Variables
Variables are containers for storing data values.
content.html: Variables are containers for storing data values.

content.text: Go Variable Types
In Go, there are different types of variables, for example:
content.html: In Go, there are different types of variables, for example:

content.text: More about different variable types, will be explained in the Go Data Types chapter.
content.html: More about different variable types, will be explained in the Go Data Types chapter.

content.text: Declaring (Creating) Variables
In Go, there are two ways to declare a variable:
content.html: In Go, there are two ways to declare a variable:

content.text: 1. With the var keyword:
Use the var keyword, followed by variable name and type:
content.html: Use the var keyword, followed by variable name and type:

content.code_html: var variablename type = value

content.text: Note: You always have to specify either type or value (or both).
content.html: Note: You always have to specify either type or value (or both).

content.text: 2. With the := sign:
Use the := sign, followed by the variable value:
content.html: Use the := sign, followed by the variable value:

content.text: Note: In this case, the type of the variable is inferred from the value (means that the compiler decides the type of the variable, based on the value).
content.html: Note: In this case, the type of the variable is inferred from the value (means that the compiler decides the type of the variable, based on the value).

content.text: Note: It is not possible to declare a variable using := , without assigning a value to it.
content.html: Note: It is not possible to declare a variable using :=, without assigning a value to it.

content.text: Variable Declaration With Initial Value
If the value of a variable is known from the start, you can declare the variable and assign a value to it on one line:
content.html: If the value of a variable is known from the start, you can declare the variable and assign a value to it on one line:

content.code:
package main
import ("fmt")
func main() {
var student1 string = "John" //type is
string
      var student2 = "Jane" 

      x := 2 

 
  fmt.Println(student1)

      fmt.Println(student2)

      fmt.Println(x)

    }
content.code_html:
package main
import ("fmt")

func main() {
  var student1 string = "John" //type is string
  var student2 = "Jane" //type is inferred
  x := 2 //type is inferred

  fmt.Println(student1)
  fmt.Println(student2)
  fmt.Println(x)
}

content.text: Note: The variable types of student2 and x is inferred from their values.
content.html: Note: The variable types of student2 and x is inferred from their values.

content.text: Variable Declaration Without Initial Value
In Go, all variables are initialized. So, if you declare a variable without an initial value, its value will be set to the default value of its type:
content.html: In Go, all variables are initialized. So, if you declare a variable without an initial value, its value will be set to the default value of its type:

content.code_html:
package main
import ("fmt")

func main() {
  var a string
  var b int
  var c bool

  fmt.Println(a)
  fmt.Println(b)
  fmt.Println(c)
}

content.text: Example explained
In this example there are 3 variables:
content.html: In this example there are 3 variables:

content.text: These variables are declared but they have not been assigned initial values.
content.html: These variables are declared but they have not been assigned initial values.

content.text: By running the code, we can see that they already have the default values of their respective types:
content.html: By running the code, we can see that they already have the default values of their respective types:

content.text: Value Assignment After Declaration
It is possible to assign a value to a variable after it is declared. This is helpful for cases the value is not initially known.
content.html: It is possible to assign a value to a variable after it is declared. This is helpful for cases the value is not initially known.

content.code_html:
package main
import ("fmt")

func main() {
  var student1 string
  student1 = "John"
  fmt.Println(student1)
}

content.text: Note: It is not possible to declare a variable using " := " without assigning a value to it.
content.html: Note: It is not possible to declare a variable using ":=" without assigning a value to it.

content.text: Difference Between var and :=
There are some small differences between the var var := :
content.html: There are some small differences between the var var :=:

content.code_html:
var :=
Can be used inside and outside of functions Can only be used inside functions
Variable declaration and value assignment can be done separately Variable declaration and value assignment cannot be done separately (must be done in the same line)

syntaxHighlighting.text:
package main
    import ("fmt")

    var a int
    var b int = 2
    var c = 3

    func main() {
      a = 1
      fmt.Println(a)
      fmt.Println(b)
      fmt.Println(c)
    }

content.code:
package main
import ("fmt")
var a int
var b int = 2
var c = 3
func main() {
a = 1
fmt.Println(a)
fmt.Println(b)
fmt.Println(c)
}

    func main() {

content.code_html:
package main
import ("fmt")

var a int
var b int = 2
var c = 3

func main() {
  a = 1
  fmt.Println(a)
  fmt.Println(b)
  fmt.Println(c)
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
package main
    import ("fmt")

    var a int
    var b int = 2
    var c = 3

    func main() {
      a = 1
      fmt.Println(a)
      fmt.Println(b)
      fmt.Println(c)
    }

content.code_html:
package main
import ("fmt")

a := 1

func main() {
  fmt.Println(a)
}
